title: From our Files
body_text:
From our Files
100 years – December 6, 1923
The contract for the construction of the state road from Oak Grove to the Iron County line will be let during January, according to Project Engineer Lamb, after a conference yesterday with department engineers. The necessary engineering work will be done within the next few days and without doubt the job will be in the next bunch of lettings, the date of which has not been definitely fixed but will doubtless be the latter part of January.
Miss Oma White and Floyd Sanders, well known young people, surprised their many friends Saturday evening by quietly going to the Baptist parsonage and being married by Rev. Wm. England. They were accompanied by Miss Bessie and Eugene Brazzell.
The M.E. Gilloiz Construction Co. of Monett, Mo. will build the Marquand bridge, according to information given out by the Sikeston office a few hours after this paper went to press last week. The price at which the contract was let is $28,106.59, almost $5,000 less than the engineer’s estimates. There were eleven bidders and the highest was substantially at the engineer’s estimates.
Regardless of the rain Thanksgiving day, the Perryville high school football squad came over here to play a return game with the F.H.S. Bulldogs. Having beaten the Bulldogs at Perryville November 23, they were sure of victory again, but were doomed to receive a very unpleasant surprise. The Bulldogs were victors by a score of 13-7. Both teams fought hard but clean, and football fans said it was the best game the Bulldogs played this season.
75 years – December 9, 1948
One man was fatally hurt and four other persons injured, two seriously, when the 1940 Ford coach they were riding in plunged off Highway 67 and down a 65-foot embankment about 12 miles south of Fredericktown Sunday evening about five o’clock.
Miss Grace H. Jones of Knob Lick and James E. Whitener of Zion, were married last Saturday, December 4 at Silva, MO by the Rev. L.A. Davis. The couple will make their home in Knob Lick at present. Both are well-known to residents of this county and St. Francois County.
It became known this week that John Sample, former representative in the State Legislature from Madison County, has purchased the store of the late Sam Najim, Sr. at Mineral Point, MO. It was not learned whether Sample would operate the store himself or if it would be in the hands of his son. Mrs. Najim plans to move to Madison County where she will build a home on Highway 70.
(photo) While hundreds of persons were looking for deer this week, Tom Ward of Route 2 was getting another species of game. Following several raids on his flock of chickens, Ward leveled down on this hawk with a rifle and brought him down. The chicken-hawk had a wing-spread of four feet and three inches.
50 years – December 6, 1973
The student body at Fredericktown High School has elected Student Council representatives for the 1973-74 school year. Rebecca Hopkins, Monica Anthony, Paula Bok, Nancy Payne, Missy Tinnin, Jana Griffon, Judy Hinkle, Greg Venker, Donna Burnham, Mike Montgomery, Patty Warren, Debbie Hufford, Tammy Ward and president Tom Roed.
Residents may soon have the opportunity to vote on whether or not this county will have a 60-bed nursing home, paid for by revenue of the home and not property taxes or obligation bonds. Administrator Patrict Lennon of Madison Memorial Hospital disclosed temporary plans to The Democrat-News last Friday after a meeting of the Trustees of Madison Memorial was held Thursday night.
Just when the Black Cats seem ready to fold, they pick themselves off the floor and come back scratching. The team won its season opener on a final second shot, and, in the recent Farmington Invitational Tournament, the Cats bounced back from a bitter defeat to capture third place.
(photo) Scott Anderson has been named by the United Press International as the All Big Eight center. He starred for the Tigers of the University of Missouri this fall and is the son of Don ‘Diz’ Anderson, former football coach at Fredericktown High School. In this photo he prepares to block an Oklahoma State gridder in a 13-9 Tiger victory. Missouri will soon begin preparations for its Dec. 29 date with Auburn in the Sun Bowl at El Paso, Tex.
25 years – December 9, 1998
After nearly 70 years at the same location, Gifford Lumber Co. in Fredericktown has built an entirely new facility. The new store will open at 7 a.m., Monday, December 14. Gifford’s will be busily moving into the new facility, this weekend. The new building is located along Highway 67 near the city limits of Fredericktown. It will have much better access and visibility.
Recently 29 cadets of the Blackcats Battalion made an overnight visit to Fort Leonard Wood. The cadets arrived at the post’s Reception Battalion where new recruits are processed into the Army. A Drill Sergeant led the group through the battalion area. After the tour the cadets had dinner of roast beef or shrimp Creole at the battalion’s dining hall. The remainder of the evening was spent cleaning barracks that the cadets occupied for the night.
Chris Clark, a seventh grader at Fredericktown Middle School has won a boom box for accumulating 250 points in the Accelerated Reading Program at the school. This prize is available to all the seventh and eighth grade students who accumulate 250 points. Sixth grade students receive a 13” T.V. Those in the photo were Chris Clark, Librarian Judith Weber, Principal John Eck and English Teacher Kathy Kegley-Moore.
Jason Dees of Marquand, Missouri, has just returned from Missouri Auction School where he successfully completed the course in Auctioneering and Auction Sales Management. He received his diploma along with men and women auctioneers from throughout the United States and Canada.
